misconceptions.name: Reads the wrong number and type of inputs
misconceptions.description: The program reads three double values instead of five integers as required, so it cannot process the correct data set for the problem.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes they should read three numeric inputs (v0, v1, t) as doubles from the user.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read exactly five integer values from the user (e.g., using nextInt in a loop or repeated calls) to later sum the even ones.
symptoms: Only three inputs are requested
Inputs are stored as double rather than int
No way to provide five separate integers
misconceptions.root_cause: Misinterpretation of the problem statement, possibly copying a solution for a different physics-style input problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Change the input to read five integers (using nextInt) and ensure that the program collects all five values, e.g., inside a loop.
related_concepts: Mapping problem requirements to input variables
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The prompt string and variable names (v0, v1, t) clearly refer to a different problem; only three doubles are read, not five ints.

evidence.snippet:
System.out.print("Enter v0, v1, and t: ");
double v0=s.nextDouble(),v1=s.nextDouble(),t=s.nextDouble();
evidence.note: Reads three double values (v0, v1, t) instead of five integers required by the problem.

misconceptions.name: Missing logic to identify even numbers
misconceptions.description: The program never checks whether any input value is even; there is no conditional or modulo operation related to evenness.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that they only need to compute a formula (average acceleration) on three inputs, with no need to distinguish even from odd numbers.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must test each of the five input integers with a condition like n % 2 == 0 and include only even numbers in the sum.
symptoms: No if-statement or conditional logic referencing evenness
No use of modulo operator (%) in the program
misconceptions.root_cause: Failure to implement the core requirement of filtering even numbers, likely due to solving a different problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: After reading each integer, use an if (n % 2 == 0) check before adding it to the sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code contains no conditions or % operator anywhere; it cannot possibly distinguish even from odd values.

evidence.note: Main method has no if-statement or modulo operation to test whether numbers are even.

misconceptions.name: Implements a different formula instead of summing even numbers
misconceptions.description: The student computes an average acceleration formula ( (v1 - v0) / t ) rather than summing even numbers from the inputs.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes the task is to compute and print "The average acceleration" from v0, v1, and t.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should maintain an integer accumulator that adds only even inputs, and then print the sum as "Sum of even numbers: X".
symptoms: Output label refers to average acceleration instead of sum of even numbers
Final result is (v1 - v0) / t, not a sum over several inputs
misconceptions.root_cause: Student likely reused code from a different exercise involving physics formulas instead of implementing the required summation algorithm.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the average acceleration calculation with an integer sum variable that adds each even input, then print the sum with the required label.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Prompt text and printed message explicitly mention average acceleration and use velocities and time variables, which are unrelated to summing even numbers.

evidence.note: Program computes and prints average acceleration instead of summing even numbers, and the output label does not match the required problem.

misconceptions.task: Reading 5 integers from input, Loop structure to process inputs, Conditional check for even numbers (n % 2 == 0), Accumulating sum and printing result
misconceptions.name: Complete Deviation from Assignment Requirements
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program for a completely different task (calculating average acceleration) instead of the required task (reading 5 integers and summing the even ones). Consequently, all core logic elements (reading 5 inputs, iteration, conditional checking for even/odd, and sum accumulation) are missing.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have copied or written code for an unrelated problem (average acceleration calculation) and submitted it for this assignment.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The solution must involve reading five integers (e.g., in a loop), checking if each is even (using the modulo operator), and adding only the even ones to an accumulator variable.
symptoms: Code reads 3 double values instead of 5 integers
Code calculates acceleration using a formula instead of performing summation
Required control flow (loops, conditionals) is absent
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding of the assignment prompt or a submission error where code for a different problem was submitted.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the assignment prompt again. You must write code that specifically addresses the requirements: iterative input, modulus check for even numbers, and using an accumulator variable.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code solves a known, standard physics problem (average acceleration) and shows zero structural or semantic relation to the assigned task (summing even numbers).

evidence.snippet:
System.out.print("Enter v0, v1, and t: ");
double v0=s.nextDouble(),v1=s.nextDouble(),t=s.nextDouble();
evidence.note: Reads three double inputs using variable names related to physics/kinematics, not five integers.
The output is a calculation of average acceleration, confirming the student solved the wrong problem and omitted summation logic.

misconceptions.name: Complete task misunderstanding - solving wrong problem
misconceptions.description: The student has submitted code that solves a completely different problem (calculating average acceleration from physics) instead of the assigned problem (summing even numbers). This indicates either a fundamental misunderstanding of the requirements or submission of code from a different assignment.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe this physics acceleration calculation code satisfies the requirement to read 5 integers and sum the even numbers.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading exactly 5 integers and calculating the sum of only those that are even (divisible by 2). The correct approach involves a loop to read 5 values, a conditional to check if each is even, and an accumulator to sum matching values.
symptoms: Code reads 3 doubles (v0, v1, t) instead of 5 integers
Code calculates acceleration (v1-v0)/t instead of sum of even numbers
No loop structure to process multiple inputs
No conditional checking for even numbers
No accumulator for summing values
Output format completely different from specification
misconceptions.root_cause: Student submitted code from a different assignment or failed to read/understand the problem statement. The physics problem (average acceleration) has no relationship to the assigned even-number sum problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Carefully read the problem statement. Write a loop that runs 5 times. In each iteration, read an integer. Check if it's even using modulo operator (n % 2 == 0). If even, add it to a running sum. After the loop, print the sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Extremely high confidence - the submitted code solves a completely different problem (physics calculation) with no resemblance to the even-number sum requirement. This is not a minor logic error but a fundamental mismatch between assignment and submission.

evidence.note: This code reads 3 doubles for a physics calculation, completely unrelated to reading 5 integers and summing even numbers as required by the problem.
No loop structure (required for processing 5 inputs), no modulo/conditional logic for checking even numbers, no accumulator pattern for summing.

misconceptions.name: Using double instead of int for input values
misconceptions.description: Even if this code were intended for the sum-of-evens problem, it incorrectly reads doubles instead of integers. The problem explicitly requires reading 5 integers, and even-number checking requires integer arithmetic.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student may believe that doubles can be used interchangeably with integers for this problem, or that the modulo operator works the same way with both types.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The problem requires reading integers (whole numbers), not floating-point doubles. Use Scanner.nextInt() for integer input. While Java allows modulo on doubles, the problem semantics require integer values.
symptoms: nextDouble() used instead of nextInt()
Variables declared as double instead of int
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion about data types and when to use int vs double. The student may not understand that integers are required for this problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Change 'double' to 'int' and use s.nextInt() instead of s.nextDouble().
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: While the main issue is solving the wrong problem entirely, this represents a secondary misconception about data types that would also cause failure even if the problem logic were correct.

evidence.note: Using double and nextDouble() instead of int and nextInt() as required for reading integer input.

Reads only three values instead of five
Variable names (v0, v1, t) do not correspond to the problem statement about integers and sums

related_concepts: Matching input specification to problem requirements
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The prompt string and variable names clearly correspond to an acceleration problem, and all three inputs are doubles, not five integers.

misconceptions.name: No loop used to process multiple inputs
misconceptions.description: The student does not use any loop to process multiple inputs, even though the problem requires handling five numbers, which is most naturally done with a loop.
misconceptions.student_belief: It is acceptable to read a fixed small number of values directly without using a loop for this task.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: When a problem requires processing several similar inputs (like 5 numbers), a loop should typically be used to avoid repetitive code and ensure scalability.
symptoms: All inputs are read via separate nextDouble calls
No for, while, or do-while loop is present to iterate over the 5 inputs
misconceptions.root_cause: Either misunderstanding that the task involves repeated, similar operations, or habit of writing separate input statements rather than using loops.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Introduce a for-loop that runs 5 times, reading one integer on each iteration and processing it. This avoids hardcoding multiple input statements.
related_concepts: Iterating over a fixed count of inputs
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: There is no loop construct anywhere in main, despite the requirement to handle five numbers.

evidence.note: main contains only a few sequential statements and no for/while/do-while loop to iterate over 5 inputs.
